- final_answer(your_final_answer: str) -> str ; final_answer your final answer to the user

- read_document(document_path: str) -> str ; read_document will return the content of the document
- read_chunk(document_path: str, chunk_number: int) -> str ; read_chunk will return the content of a document chunk (index starts at 0)
- journalist(subject: str, style: str, length: str, language: str) -> str ; journalist will write a news report with great skill about any subject

Note: You will not make use of composite functions.
The following are the files you can work with. Always write their full path.

have affected the Amazonian carbon balance between 2010-2018 compared to 2019 and 2020,
based on atmospheric CO: vertical profiles*®, deforestation’ and fire data’, and infraction notices
related to illegal deforestation’. We estimate that Amazonia carbon emissions increased from
0.24+0.08 PgC y! 2010-18 mean to 0.44+0.10 in 2019 and 0.52+0.10 PgC y" in 2020 (+
uncertainty). The observed increase in deforestation were 82% and 77% (94% accuracy) and
burned area of 14% and 42% in 2019 and 2020 compared to the 2010-2018 mean, respectively.
We find that the number of notifications of infractions against flora decreased by 30% and 54%
and fines paid by 74% and 89% in 2019 and 2020, respectively. Carbon losses during 2019-20
were comparable to the record warm El Nino (2015-16) without an extreme drought event.
Statistical tests show that the observed differences between 2010-18 mean and 2019-20 are
unlikely to have arisen by chance. The changes in Amazonia’s carbon budget during 2019-20
were mainly due to western Amazonia becoming a carbon source. Our results suggest that a
decline in law enforcement led to increases in deforestation, biomass burning and forest
degradation which increased carbon emissions and enhanced drying and warming of the Amazon
forests.
Introduction
Amazonia hosts the largest tropical forest on the planet and has proven to be an important carbon
sink in the recent past'~, This carbon sink is declining, mainly due to increased tree mortality!
as a result of deforestation and climate change‘. The Amazon Forest represents around 50% of
the global tropical rainforest and contains about 90 Pg C in above and below ground vegetation
biomass'-"', which can be quickly released and thus result in substantial positive feedback on

Output: actas a carbon sink’ *",
In the Amazon the relationships between ecosystem carbon and water cycles and climate are
complex. Several studies have estimated that evapotranspiration is responsible for up to 50% of
water recirculation in Amazonian precipitation. Hydrologically, Amazonia is one of the three
main air upwelling regions in the tropics and rainfall in the whole basin averages about 2,200
mm per year'*, Large-scale human disturbance alters these ecosystem-climate interactions. In the
last 40 to 50 years, human impact has increasingly affected Amazonia, resulting in a forest loss
of around 18%, of which 14% has been converted mainly to agricultural land (89% pastures and
10% crops)*.
Ithas been widely reported that illegal deforestation rose 80% since 2019”, compared to the 2010-
18 period as a result of changes in law enforcement policy. We analysed how these changes affect
the Amazonian carbon balance and how they are linked to deforestation and fire feedbacks.
Forest removal reduces evapotranspiration and rainfall while increasing temperature!S'8,
Additionally, regional deforestation followed by fires and selective logging causes degradation
of adjacent forests, increasing vulnerability to fires'. Regional and global warming are
synergistic and mutually reinforcing.
We compared the mean Amazonian carbon balance over 9 years (2010-18)! with the subsequent
two years (2019 and 2020). In this recent period, there has been an intense reduction in public
policies to control deforestation'®. We used deforestation data analysis map to georeferenced
carbon sources (limited to the Brazilian Amazon — PRODES), as well as fire spots incidence
(Pan-Amaz6nia) and burned area, in addition to other parameters (see methods) to understand
the main factors responsible for converting the Amazonia into a carbon source.
